title: Catholic Philosophy
summary: Catholic philosophy is the rich intellectual tradition of the Church — from Augustine through Aquinas and beyond — that has brought Greek reason and Christian revelation into creative dialogue, insisting that faith and reason are complementary paths to truth and producing in the Scholastic movement some of the greatest philosophical and theological work in human history.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Fire
summary: Fire is the rapid chemical reaction between fuel and oxygen that releases heat and light, and the mastery of fire is what first separated humanity from every other creature on Earth. In the Bible, fire appears as a profound symbol of God's presence, holiness, and purifying work.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Chinese Philosophy
summary: Chinese philosophy is one of the oldest and most distinctive intellectual traditions in the world, encompassing the great schools of Confucianism, Taoism, and Legalism born in the turbulent Warring States period, as well as the Chinese forms of Buddhism — traditions that shaped East Asian civilization as profoundly as Plato and Aristotle shaped the West.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Oceans
summary: The oceans cover more than 70 percent of Earth's surface and contain over 97 percent of all the water on our planet, regulating climate, supporting extraordinary biodiversity, and shaping human civilization from the ancient seafarers to the Age of Exploration.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Western Philosophy
summary: Western philosophy is the great intellectual tradition stretching from ancient Greece through Rome, medieval Christendom, the Renaissance, the Enlightenment, and into the modern era — a twenty-five-century conversation about reality, knowledge, morality, and the good society that has been shaped at every stage by the creative tension between Greek reason and Christian faith.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Forests
summary: Forests are complex, multi-layered communities of trees and organisms that cover about 31 percent of Earth's land surface, performing essential ecological services, sheltering extraordinary biodiversity, and sustaining human civilizations since the beginning of recorded history.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Eastern Philosophy
summary: Eastern philosophy encompasses the rich and diverse philosophical traditions of Asia — the Hindu philosophies of India, the Buddhist traditions flowering across the continent, the Confucian and Taoist schools of China, and the contemplative traditions of Japan and Korea — addressing the same fundamental questions as Western philosophy from strikingly different starting points.
author: EduWiki Team

title: The Moon
summary: The Moon is Earth's only natural satellite — created by God as the 'lesser light to rule the night' — governing tides, measuring time, inspiring poets and theologians for millennia, and serving as the destination of the Apollo missions, one of humanity's greatest achievements.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Indian Philosophy
summary: Indian philosophy is one of the oldest and deepest philosophical traditions in the world — stretching from the Vedas and Upanishads through the six orthodox Hindu schools, the heterodox traditions of Buddhism and Jainism, and the great medieval Vedanta debates — addressing questions of the self, ultimate reality, liberation, and right action with extraordinary sophistication.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Planets
summary: Planets are large celestial bodies orbiting a star, and our solar system's eight worlds — from scorched Mercury to icy Neptune — testify to the extraordinary variety of God's creative work and have fascinated astronomers and philosophers for thousands of years.
author: EduWiki Team

title: World Religions
summary: The study of world religions is among the most important and humanizing of intellectual pursuits — a survey of how billions of human beings across history have answered the deepest questions of existence, from the Abrahamic faiths of the Middle East to the Dharmic traditions of India and the philosophical religions of East Asia.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Galaxies
summary: Galaxies are vast systems of billions of stars bound together by gravity — the fundamental building blocks of the universe's large-scale structure. Our Milky Way is one of hundreds of billions of galaxies, making the heavens' declaration of God's glory more staggering than any ancient stargazer could have imagined.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Abrahamic Religions
summary: The Abrahamic religions — Judaism, Christianity, and Islam — are the three great monotheistic faiths tracing their spiritual ancestry to the patriarch Abraham, together followed by more than half of humanity and having shaped the history, law, philosophy, art, and politics of human civilization more profoundly than any other religious tradition.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Astrophysics
summary: Astrophysics applies the laws of physics and chemistry to understand stars, galaxies, and the universe itself — from the Big Bang to black holes, from gravitational waves to dark matter — a field of inquiry that has deepened both scientific knowledge and wonder at the Creator's handiwork.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Christianity
summary: Christianity is the world's largest religion — the faith of more than two billion people and the spiritual, moral, and intellectual foundation of Western civilization — centered on the person and work of Jesus Christ: his incarnation, crucifixion, bodily resurrection, and the promise of eternal life to all who trust in him.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Latter-day Saint Philosophy
summary: Latter-day Saint philosophy is one of the most distinctive and original theological-philosophical systems in the modern world, introducing through Joseph Smith's Restoration a set of metaphysical and anthropological claims — an embodied God, eternal intelligences, the materiality of spirit, and the destiny of eternal progression — that challenge the basic assumptions of classical Western theology.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Ancient Egypt
summary: Ancient Egypt is one of the greatest civilizations in human history — flourishing for more than three thousand years along the Nile, producing the pyramids, hieroglyphics, and a sophisticated religion — and holds a unique place in Christian and Jewish faith as the land of Israel's sojourn, the stage of the Exodus, and the training ground of Moses.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Rivers
summary: Rivers are the arteries of the earth — flowing channels of fresh water that have nourished every great civilization in history, shaped the landscapes we inhabit, and served as powerful symbols of life, purification, and divine provision from the rivers of Eden to the Jordan where Christ was baptized.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Biology
summary: Biology is the scientific study of living organisms — from the chemistry of a single cell to the dynamics of a global ecosystem — and stands as one of the most profound explorations of God's creation, revealing at every level the extraordinary complexity, beauty, and purposeful design woven through all living things.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Chemistry
summary: Chemistry is the science of matter — its composition, structure, properties, and transformations — probing the material fabric of God's creation at its most fundamental level and giving humanity the tools to understand, heal, and care for the physical world.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Human Anatomy
summary: Human anatomy is the science of the structure of the human body — its bones, muscles, organs, and tissues — and confirms the Psalmist's declaration that we are 'fearfully and wonderfully made,' bearing at every level the unmistakable signature of a master Designer.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Human Physiology
summary: Human physiology is the science of how the human body works — how its organs, tissues, and cells perform their functions and maintain homeostasis — revealing the extraordinary integration and purposeful design of the living body that Paul called the temple of the Holy Spirit.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Healthy Cooking
summary: Healthy cooking is both a practical skill and a profound act of stewardship — preparing wholesome, nourishing food in ways that honor the body God gave us, drawing on the timeless wisdom of Scripture, the Mediterranean tradition, and modern nutritional science.
author: EduWiki Team

title: United States of America
summary: The United States of America is the greatest experiment in ordered liberty in human history — a nation founded by Providence on the self-evident truths of God-given rights, whose story from the Mayflower Compact to the Constitution is inseparable from the Christian faith of its founders and the conviction that liberty is a divine endowment.
author: EduWiki Team

title: European History
summary: European history is the story of Western civilization — born in ancient Greece and Rome, transformed by Christianity, refined through medieval Christendom, and carrying into the present an inheritance of philosophy, law, science, art, and faith that has shaped the entire world.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Plato's Allegory of the Cave
summary: Plato's Allegory of the Cave — from Book VII of the Republic — is the most famous philosophical illustration in Western history, depicting prisoners who mistake shadows for reality and one who escapes into sunlight, resonating deeply with the Christian journey from spiritual blindness to the light of God.
author: EduWiki Team

title: The Holy Ghost
summary: The Holy Ghost — the divine Comforter promised by Jesus Christ — is the third person of the Trinity and a distinct member of the Godhead, present at creation, poured out at Pentecost, and dwelling in the hearts of believers as the agent of conversion, sanctification, spiritual gifts, and divine witness.
author: EduWiki Team

title: God the Father
summary: God the Father — Creator, Covenant-maker, and loving Father of all humanity — is the first person of the Godhead, the Almighty whose character and purposes are the subject of the entire Bible, and whose invitation through Jesus Christ to call him 'Abba, Father' is the most astonishing and transformative claim of the Christian gospel.
author: EduWiki Team

title: Angels
summary: Angels — the heavenly messengers and ministers of God — appear throughout Scripture from Genesis to Revelation as heralds of divine communication, guardians of God's people, and worshippers before the throne of the Almighty, bearing persistent testimony to the reality of the spiritual world and God's active presence in human affairs.
author: EduWiki Team
